Arrested for stealing a hair dryer; changes her name from Sandy to Santee; suesinsurers of arson cottage for $6,000 claiming imaginary property damage.
Sante has her first child who she names Kent Walker.
Her name appears in the newspaper for adultery, because she had been sleepingwith Ed’s client since September 1961.
She arranged to have her Sacramento house burned down, to collect insurancemoney.
She moved to a condo in Burbank, CA to start a new life.
She opened several credit cards, in different names, racking up $20,000 in debtwhich she could not pay off. When the police caught on to her scam she wascharged with 17 counts of grand theft.

Santee and her boyfriend Clyde steal in Los Angeles, and then drive to PalmSprings to stash the stuff in a house that Clyde owns. They burn the house downto get insurance money for all the stolen items, and they also burn the upper halfof Ed’s Laurel Canyon house, which Ed had given her as a gift, to collectinsurance money.
Sante divorces Ed, and moves around with her young son, never staying in oneplace very long.
Smashes Ed’s window and attacks him looking for his new girlfriend. A fewweeks later Sante attacks Ed’s girlfriend in a parking lot, dragging her aroundby her hair.
Sandy and boyfriend Clyde shoot blanks at Ed on a mountain road because he“turned on them”.
Sante has Kent sneak into houses and steal things for her. This goes on for 2years.
Founded Kiosk, Forum of Man Inc. which printed posters of international andAmerican flags.
Sante made friends with C.V. Narasimhan, who was an undersecretary Generalof the United Nations, while representing the Kiosk company.
Sante met with Pat Nixon, the current first lady, about promoting Kiosk posters.
Sante got Ken a spot at the Rose Bowl in order to lead the fans in the pledge.
Kiosk falls apart for unknown reasons.
Sante and Ken Kimes party hop around DC (uninvited), and end up in an articlein the Washington Post.
Sante was charged with grand theft for stealing something from a shop inNewport Beach; it was thought to be a gift for her son’s birthday. She got off on$250 fine, and two years probation.
Checks into hospital for “minor surgery”, and gives birth to her second sonKenneth [Kenny] Kimes.
Kent was arrested for stealing surfboards. Sante was angry because he was notcareful and he got caught.
She leaves Kent with Ken’s nephew for a couple of hours, but doesn’t return forabout a month.
She is referred to as Ken Kimes’ wife, because they had been together for solong.
The Kimes family moves to Honolulu.
Kent runs away to be with his father several times, and Ed soon gets custody ofhis son.
Sante burns down Honolulu house, to collect insurance money. The firemencould tell it was arson but insurance still paid.
Ken leaves because he can’t deal with Sante anymore, but eventually comesback.
The Kimes family moves to Las Vegas because Sante wants a new start.
Kent rats out Santee to police for enslaving homeless people and illegal aliens tomake them her slaves, but nothing happens to Sante.
Sante is arrested for stealing a mink coat in a bar, in Washington DC; she doesnot get caught doing this.
Sante hires a hit man to kill Jeff David because he refused to help their realestate scam.
Possibly a Vegas ceremony was held for Ken Kimes and Sante.
Sante’s first grandchild, Kristina, was born to Kent Walker.
She goes to trial for mink coat case, and she was convicted of grand larceny, butshe bailed herself out before the verdict was made.
Sante and Ken Kimes were arrested on 17 charges of involuntary servitude andtransporting illegal aliens.
Sante escapes from jail.
The slave trial begins, and Sante is convicted of 14 counts of slaveholding,escaping from prison, and transporting illegal aliens. She was sentenced to 5years in a high security prison.
She was transferred from Clark County, NV Jail to Pleasanton, CA.
She returned to the mink coat trial, and she was sentenced to 3-9 years.
She was transferred to Washington DC to serve the mink coat sentence.
Grand larceny verdict for the theft of the mink coat is overturned on appeal.
She was released from prison, and ran up $10,000 in credit card debt before herfamily knew she was out.
Hires someone to burn her Honolulu house again, because there was a lien onthe property, and it would cost them $900,000 when they wanted to sell it.
Hires someone to burn her lawyer’s office, because he had a lot of papers thatrelated to her case that would be able to incriminate her.

Kills Elmer Holmgren because he confessed to a friend about taking part in theburning of the lawyer’s office. He was killed by being hit in the head with ahammer by Sante who was in the backseat while he was riding in the frontpassenger’s seat. His body was never found.
Ken and Sante move to the Bahamas, to start over again.
Ken dies of aneurysm; Sante uses this as an advantage to get what she wantsfrom people.
Syed Bilal Ahmed disappears after having dinner with Sante, to discuss Kensbank accounts.
Sante burns down her Las Vegas house for insurance money.

Sante sends Kenny and other guy to kill David Kazdin because he threatened toexpose them for burning the Las Vegas house. He was shot to death and hisbody was dumped in a dumpster and found by homeless man.
Kenny rents an apartment from Irene Silverman who was a rich widow living inNew York City.

Irene Silverman (82) was killed by Sante and Kenny. She was shot in the headby a stun gun to paralyze her, strangled by Kenny, wrapped in garbage bags, andstuffed in a suitcase. Sante and Kenny were arrested for murder of IreneSilverman later that day, and the body was never found, though it is probably inNJ.

During the case of Irene Silverman, Sante was indicted for possession ofweapons, forged documents, stolen property, robbery, attempted robbery, grandlarceny, attempted grand larceny, eavesdropping and second degree murder.
Sante has an interview with 60 Minutes to discuss the Irene Silverman case.
Charges filed for murder of David Kazdin (64), and the charges were added onto her sentence.
Silverman trial begins.

Sante and Kenny found guilty of all 118 counts brought against, including thesecond degree murder of Irene Silverman who kept a notebook of her suspicionsof Sante, and Sante’s notebook detailing the crime.
Sante is sentenced to 120 years in the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility forWomen located in New York.
Court of Appeal of California affirmed Sante’s conviction in the murder ofDavid Kazdin.
New York Appeals Court affirms Sante’s conviction for the murder of IreneSilverman.
